conclusion: Consider direction of A's movement, arrangement of blocks, and potential deflections due to collisions.
A is moving from the lower right towards the group of blocks.
Assume A has enough momentum to cause noticeable collisions.
First block A will likely hit is the orange block closest to the lower right corner.
Upon collision, the orange block will be pushed forward, potentially causing a chain reaction.
After hitting the orange block, A might continue moving forward and could hit the yellow block next to it.
The yellow block, if hit, will also move forward and may collide with the other yellow block nearby.
Depending on angle and force of collisions, A might get deflected slightly to the left or right.
If A has enough momentum after these collisions, it might continue moving and hit the red blocks further up.
If collisions significantly reduce A's momentum, it might come to a stop near the initial point of impact.
A will likely come to a stop near the area where it initially hits the orange block.
Exact final position will depend on specifics of each collision, but should be close to initial impact point.
A will collide with the orange block first, followed by the yellow block, and possibly the red blocks if it retains enough momentum.
